Posts.Content: Nicole, Please know that you are not alone, it just feels that way. I hope you know by the wonderful responses you have received that strangers love and care about you. Reach out, keep communicating and live the life that you presently have with her. There will be time to grieve, but while she is alive, share the moments, make memories and love each other abundantly. It is a sad journey and I am so very sorry. Keep the faith and know that I and many others care about your situation and possible loss. Karen
Posts.Title: Lost, Alone, and in Need of Advice

Posts.Content: I'd like to discuss how my husband reacted to the news of breast cancer and would be interested in other views. Monday, 4/8/13, I have surgery for DCIS and I am okay with getting the procedure done and hopefully moving past the diagnosis, but what really changed my life was my relationship with my husband when I was diagnosed with cancer. I think he felt threatened by the possibility of losing me. He needed me to support him and reassure him that we will be okay. To be honest, somedays I was able and other days, I quietly cried in the corner. It has been difficult trying to support him emotionally and myself. I don't believe this journey is all about me, but I feel as though I am a vortex and my breath is being sucked out of me. A 42 year marriage being redefined...
Posts.Title: Husbands

Posts.Content: Piper, I am so sorry to hear of such a tragic event. How are you today? I do enjoy my husband immensley, but I worry that he is going to make himself sick worrying about me. I agree with your friends about your husband stressing cause I have one of those! They can't help themselves, they kind of like or liked us. As you stated, "no guarantees for tomorrow", I am very aware. This moment is all we have and I know it. Please let me know how you are today. Karen
